Package org.numpy4j.linalg

Class LinearAlgebra

java.lang.Object
org.numpy4j.linalg.LinearAlgebra
public class LinearAlgebra extends Object
A utility class providing core linear algebra operations on NDArray objects, including vector and matrix computations such as dot products, matrix multiplication, transposition, norms, determinants, inverses, and identity matrix creation.

This class is intended as a lightweight alternative to libraries such as NumPy or BLAS, supporting small to medium-sized datasets directly in pure Java.

Example Usage:


 NDArray a = new NDArray(new double[]{1, 2, 3});
 NDArray b = new NDArray(new double[]{4, 5, 6});
 double dot = LinearAlgebra.dot(a, b); // 32.0

 NDArray A = new NDArray(new double[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 2, 2);
 NDArray B = new NDArray(new double[]{5, 6, 7, 8}, 2, 2);
 NDArray C = LinearAlgebra.matmul(A, B);
 // C = [[19, 22],
 //      [43, 50]]

 NDArray T = LinearAlgebra.transpose(A);
 // T = [[1, 3],
 //      [2, 4]]

  • Method Details

    • dot

      public static double dot(NDArray a, NDArray b)
      Computes the dot product (inner product) of two 1D vectors.

      This operation sums the elementwise products: 

      
 dot(a, b) = a‚ÇÅ¬∑b‚ÇÅ + a‚ÇÇ¬∑b‚ÇÇ + ... + a‚Çô¬∑b‚Çô
      Parameters:
      a - the first 1D vector
      b - the second 1D vector
      Returns:
      the dot product as a scalar value
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the vectors have different lengths

      Example:

      
 NDArray a = new NDArray(new double[]{1, 2, 3});
 NDArray b = new NDArray(new double[]{4, 5, 6});
 double result = LinearAlgebra.dot(a, b); // 32.0

    • matmul

      public static NDArray matmul(NDArray A, NDArray B)
      Performs matrix multiplication between two 2D matrices: 
      
 C = A √ó B

      The number of columns in A must match the number of rows in B. The result is an m√óp matrix, where:

      • m = A.rows
      • p = B.cols
      Parameters:
      A - the left-hand matrix
      B - the right-hand matrix
      Returns:
      a new NDArray representing the product matrix C
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if either input is not 2D or shapes are incompatible

      Example:

      
 NDArray A = new NDArray(new double[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 2, 2);
 NDArray B = new NDArray(new double[]{5, 6, 7, 8}, 2, 2);
 NDArray C = LinearAlgebra.matmul(A, B);
 // C = [[19, 22],
 //      [43, 50]]

    • transpose

      public static NDArray transpose(NDArray A)
      Returns the transpose of a 2D matrix.

      The rows and columns are swapped: 

      
 A·µÄ[i, j] = A[j, i]
      Parameters:
      A - the input 2D matrix
      Returns:
      a new NDArray representing the transposed matrix
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the input is not a 2D matrix

      Example:

      
 NDArray A = new NDArray(new double[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 2, 2);
 NDArray T = LinearAlgebra.transpose(A);
 // T = [[1, 3],
 //      [2, 4]]

    • norm

      public static double norm(NDArray A)
      Computes the Euclidean (L2) norm of a vector: 
      
 ||A||‚ÇÇ = sqrt(a‚ÇÅ¬≤ + a‚ÇÇ¬≤ + ... + a‚Çô¬≤)
      Parameters:
      A - a 1D vector
      Returns:
      the L2 norm (magnitude) of the vector

      Example:

      
 NDArray v = new NDArray(new double[]{3, 4});
 double n = LinearAlgebra.norm(v); // 5.0

    • det

      public static double det(NDArray A)
      Computes the determinant of a square matrix using recursive Laplace expansion.

      This implementation is simple but not efficient for large matrices (O(n!)).

      Parameters:
      A - a square matrix (n√ón)
      Returns:
      the determinant of the matrix
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the input is not square

      Example:

      
 NDArray A = new NDArray(new double[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 2, 2);
 double det = LinearAlgebra.det(A); // -2.0

    • inv

      public static NDArray inv(NDArray A)
      Computes the inverse of a square matrix using Gaussian elimination.

      This method augments the matrix with the identity and applies row operations to transform [A | I] ‚Üí [I | A‚Åª¬π].

      Parameters:
      A - the input square matrix
      Returns:
      the inverse matrix A‚Åª¬π as an NDArray
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the matrix is not square
      ArithmeticException - if the matrix is singular (non-invertible)

      Example:

      
 NDArray A = new NDArray(new double[]{4, 7, 2, 6}, 2, 2);
 NDArray inv = LinearAlgebra.inv(A);
 // inv ‚âà [[0.6, -0.7],
 //         [-0.2, 0.4]]

    • eye

      public static NDArray eye(int n)
      Creates an identity matrix of size n√ón.

      The identity matrix has ones on the main diagonal and zeros elsewhere: 

      
 eye(3) =
 [[1, 0, 0],
  [0, 1, 0],
  [0, 0, 1]]
      Parameters:
      n - the number of rows and columns
      Returns:
      an n√ón identity matrix as an NDArray

      Example:

      
 NDArray I = LinearAlgebra.eye(3);
 // [[1, 0, 0],
 //  [0, 1, 0],
 //  [0, 0, 1]]
